item.title: Opinion: Studying Ebola, Then Dying From It
item.description: We could have stopped this epidemic, and saved my colleagues’ lives.
item.dc:creator: By PARDIS SABETI
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nurses at Kenema Hospital in Sierra Leone in August.

item.title: Opinion: Why Scotland Should Stick With Britain
item.description: The four countries of Britain share values — and a democracy that represents them.
item.dc:creator: By GORDON BROWN

item.title: Small Plane Heading From Rochester to Florida Crashes Off Jamaica; 2 Are Killed
item.description: Larry Glazer, a real estate developer from the Rochester area, and his wife, Jane, were aboard the single-engine aircraft, which was attempting a descent after overshooting its destination.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN FEUER

item.title: Russia Detains Estonian Officer, Raising Tensions
item.description: Estonia accused Russia of kidnapping an intelligence officer, while Moscow suggested he was a spy, heightening tensions already strained over Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: At Summit, U.S. and Allies Form Coalition Against ISIS
item.description: The plan, formed on the sidelines of a NATO summit meeting, is to attack Sunni militants from the air and work to bolster allies in Iraq and Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Coalition Military Charter Plane Lands Unexpectedly in Iran
item.description: The Obama administration said the episode was a bureaucratic issue and not a larger political incident.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Ebola Vaccine Could Be Ready by November, W.H.O. Says
item.description: The organization also said blood from recovered Ebola patients should be used to develop treatments for the disease, which has killed more than 2,100.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Broken Buildings and Bruised Psyches Complicate Start of Gaza School Year
item.description: While the logistics of getting students back to school are crucial, parents and educators in Gaza face the larger challenge of educating a generation that has survived three wars in six years.
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A displaced Palestinian family eats dinner at school operated by the United Nations.

item.title: NATO Approves New Reaction Force for Eastern Europe
item.description: The decision to form the force was meant to send a message to Russia that NATO’s principle of collective security is sacrosanct.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: President Obama spoke with President François Hollande of France at the NATO summit in Newport, Wales, on Friday.

item.title: Fighting Tapers Off in Ukraine as Cease-Fire Takes Effect
item.description: The deal was negotiated by representatives of Ukraine, pro-Russian separatists, the Kremlin and Europe, and fighting around the strategic port city of Mariupol eased.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on the outskirts of Mariupol, the site of heavy clashes on Friday.

item.title: New Book Says C.I.A. Official in Benghazi Held Up Rescue
item.description: Five C.I.A. commandos write that a C.I.A. base chief stopped them from interceding in time to save the life of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens during the attack on the diplomatic mission in 2012.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: The American Mission in Benghazi, Libya, during the 2012 attack. Five C.I.A. contractors who were nearby say they were told not to intervene.

item.title: Leader of Qaeda-Linked Somali Group Is Dead, U.S. Says
item.description: The Pentagon said it had confirmed that airstrikes Monday killed the leader of the Shabab, the Somalia militant network affiliated with Al Qaeda.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Crackdown on Corruption, Even Mooncakes Are Not Exempt
item.description: No longer just a symbol of auspicious reunions, the mooncake has become an emblem of the corruption that the Chinese government under Xi Jinping is eager to stop.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By BECKY DAVIS
item.media:credit: Wang Hu/FEATURECHINA, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Mooncakes being prepared for baking ahead of the Mid-Autumn Festival.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Regulator Tightens Grip on Video Streaming Websites
item.description: Operators in the $2 billion market will have to get licenses for foreign films and TV shows.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG and SHANSHAN WANG
item.media:description: Computer users at a cafe in Beijing. Before rules announced Friday, video streaming sites operated with relative freedom compared with traditional broadcasters.

item.title: The Other Ebola Toll: African Economies
item.description: The disease, and the hysteria it has caused, is already having a serious economic impact, in part because some countries are closing down borders.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: British Response to Election Limits Upsets Activists in Hong Kong
item.description: Some advocates had hoped Britain would respond more harshly to China’s move to restrict democracy in the city.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: Dalai Lama Said to Be Denied South African Visa
item.description: Though South Africa said the application was still being processed, a representative of the Tibetan spiritual leader said he had been told it would be rejected.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why #RussiaInvadedUkraine Matters
item.description: We cannot let Putin choose our words for us. Linguistic clarity is essential to moral clarity.
item.dc:creator: By CHRYSTIA FREELAND
item.media:description: A pro-Russian separatist standing near a damaged war memorial on a hill east of Donetsk.

item.title: In Eastern Europe, Ukraine Crisis Focuses Minds on NATO and Military Spending
item.description: Eastern European nations have called for an assertive response from NATO in the face of an aggressive Russia, but many of those countries have not met the military spending commitments that come with NATO membership.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Nigeria in the Time of Ebola
item.description: The fact that the virus has so far been contained has given this nation of skeptics rare hope for our leaders.
item.dc:creator: By ADEWALE MAJA-PEARCE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Weighing in on Paid Interethnic Marriages in Xinjiang
item.description: In an effort to defuse ethnic tensions, a county in a Western region of China is trying to encourage marriage between Uighurs and Han by offering cash and other incentives. Two experts put the efforts into context.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A Uighur man trying on a traditional hat in Kashgar, Xinjiang. A Xinjiang county has offered financial incentives for marriages between Han and Uighurs or other ethnic minorities.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Militants Kidnap About 50 Men From a Village in Iraq
item.description: Militants affiliated with the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria abducted dozens of men from a Sunni village north of Baghdad on Thursday, residents said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: U.S. Seizes Assets Traced to South Korean Ex-President
item.description: The United States Justice Department has seized $500,000 traced to former President Chun Doo-hwan of South Korea, who was convicted in a South Korean court in 1997 of accepting more than $200 million in bribes while in office from 1980 to 1988.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: British Premier Offers to Expand Assistance to Kurdish Forces in Iraq
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain offered on Thursday to arm Kurdish forces fighting Islamist militants and refused to rule out British airstrikes in Iraq and possibly Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Miscommunication Blamed for Mistaken U.S. Airstrike in Afghanistan
item.description: An airstrike that mistakenly killed five American soldiers and one Afghan in June was caused by a series of avoidable instances of miscommunication among air and ground forces, according to a report by military investigators released Thursday.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
